title: Dashboards
text:
A lightweight dashboard presenting data on work stoppages (strikes and lockouts) in Canada by sector, industry, and province. This began as an experiment in responsive dashboard design with the new Quarto dashboards feature. The live charts were created using R and the Datawrapper API – probably the best part is how well they work with Quarto for creating responsive designs that work well and without too much fuss on both wide and mobile screens.

Data source: Employment and Social Development Canada, Work stoppages by sector and year.
Variables:

Work stoppages (strikes and lockouts):

number of stoppages
days not worked
stoppage duration
rates per 1K employed.


Interactivity: None, users can explore different measures using page navigation.

R: Data preparation, programmatic chart creation and styling.

title: Contact
text:
I am a researcher, analyst and data storyteller. But the point of researching, analyzing, and telling stories is to make change. I have worked with public sector education organizations, think tanks, and labour organizations to turn data and research into meaningful insights and policy tools for progress.

title: Not Just Vibes: Unionized Workers Are Feeling Real Wage Losses
text:
Economic growth is back on track, inflation is easing, and real wages have finally grown. This has led some policymakers to suggest that the cost-of-living crisis is fading. Economists now ensure us that “the economy” is doing pretty well, all things considered.
Despite this “good news” there is a prevalent mood of anger and frustration due to financial pain. How can real wages be rising, while most people perceive a rapid decline in their living standards? Some commentators have insisted that the economic perceptions of most people are just out of sync with reality. Some people just don’t know how good they really have it, right?
There are many reasons to be skeptical about this narrative, but we can start with a simple one – large groups of workers have so far been left out of the alleged wage recovery.
It is true that many workers have recently seen significant wage gains after years of stagnation. According to Labour Force Survey data, average hourly real wages (adjusted to 2024 dollars based on the all-items CPI) grew by $2.58 for men (+7.4%) and $2.88 for women (+9.7%) over the last decade. Most of these gains came in the past two years.

title: Not Just Vibes: Unionized Workers Are Feeling Real Wage Losses
text:
Great news everyone! Real wages have grown, inflation is now back to normal and GDP growth rates are back on track! Politicians, central bankers, and media pundits proclaimed with triumph that the cost of living crisis is over – real wages have finally “caught up” to inflation.
It is true that many workers have made significant wage gains after ages of stagnating pay in real terms. Over the last decade, average hourly real wages (in 2024 dollars) grew by $2.51 for men (+7.1%) and $2.83 for women (+9.5%). Most of that growth has been in the last few years.

title: Not Just Vibes: Unionized Workers Are Feeling Real Wage Losses
section: Header on union members missing out (for now)
text:
Header on union members missing out (for now)
However, those gains have not been evenly distributed. There is one group in particular that has – so far – been left out of the wage growth trend.
That would be union members, most of whom have endured stagnant or declining real wages. In the private sector, union members had paltry wage gains of just 30 cents (+0.81%) an hour from 2014 to 2024. Their public sector colleagues actually had real hourly wage losses of $1.26 (-2.5%) over that time.
It was another story for workers in non-unionized workplaces. Non-members in the private sector saw strong wage gains of $2.50 an hour (+13.9%). Non-unionized employees the public sector saw more modest gains of 40 cents an hour (+2.5%) but they are predominantly professionals and managers with already very high wages.
Why are union members, who have traditionally enjoyed higher wages, now losing out during a time of historic wage gains? To a large extent, it is down to timing and the method used to get a raise.







Much of the private sector pay bump for non-unionized workers came from job-switching. In the past few years, many workers have either lost or left low-wage jobs in favor of better jobs with higher pay. It isn’t so simple to leave one unionized job for another to get a raise. Those types of jobs are more scarce and pay structures under collective agreements are often more strictly tied to seniority.
For most union members, the only option is to wait for an existing contract to end, then hope that the next one that includes a real raise. Most collective agreements in Canada are three to five years long. Workers with contracts that were signed close to the onset of the cost-of-living crisis in 2021-2022 have witnessed their real wages sputter while they wait for a new deal.
In the years to come, it is likely that private sector workers will regain the longstanding union wage premium, as pre-COL crisis contracts expire and new deals are signed. Seeing other private sector unions get results with large-scale, co-ordinated negotiation and strike action will hopefully be a wind in the sails of union militancy.
In the public sector, unionized workers also have to contend with bargaining interference and wage suppression by governments determined run roughshod over labour rights.

title: Not Just Vibes: Unionized Workers Are Feeling Real Wage Losses
section: Even after growth, wages are still far too low
text:
Even after growth, wages are still far too low
Average private sector wages have indeed grown heartily. But have they grown enough? In the chart below, average real wages for private sector employees are shown for each quintile of hourly income over the last 10 years.
Wages have grown across the board, the most at the bottom of the wage distribution. In the lowest income quintile, average wages rose by nearly one-fifth (18.7%), which amounted to an increase of only $2.68 per hour. Workers in the next lowest quintile had healthy growth (+10.7%) as well, a pay raise of about $2.22 per hour.
Despite strong wage growth, wages for many workers are still too low, especially given the baked-in price increases in staples like food, shelter, and energy. Surely, it is not bad vibes keeping the good news from the 40% of private sector workers that have hourly earnings just above or under the average national rental wage of $22.50.






It has been a really great time to be one of the top income takers in the country. Those in the top quintile saw their wages grow by $4.35 an hour (+8.7%) landing just shy of $68 an hour, nearly four times what those at the bottom were making.

title: Not Just Vibes: Unionized Workers Are Feeling Real Wage Losses
section: Union members are being left behind
text:
Union members are being left behind
While many workers are seeing their wages grow, union members are notably missing out. Most have experienced stagnant or even declining real wages.
In the private sector, unionized workers saw their hourly wages increase by a meager 30 cents (+0.9%) from 2014 to 2024. Public sector union members fared even worse, with real hourly wages dropping by 94 cents an hour (-2.3%) over the same period.
By contrast, non-unionized workers have seen substantial wage growth. In the private sector, non-union employees enjoyed an impressive $4.15 (+14.2%) increase in hourly pay. Non-union public sector workers, primarily professionals and managers with already high earnings, experienced more modest gains of $1.12 (+2.7%).
Historically, private sector union members earned higher average wages than their non-unionized peers. But since the onset of the cost-of-living crisis in 2021-22, that advantage has eroded. Today, average wages for non-unionized workers exceed those of unionized workers by about 40 cents per hour.
In 2024, there were over 3.3 million union members in the public sector and another 2 million in the private sector – that’s about three in ten paid employees in the country who have largely been left behind as wages rise.
Why are union members, long known for securing better wages, falling behind during this period of historic wage growth?







One major factor is job-switching. Much of the wage growth among non-unionized private sector workers has been driven by employees leaving low-paying jobs for higher-paying opportunities. This path to higher earnings isn’t as straightforward for union members.
Unionized jobs, particularly in the private sector, are relatively scarce. Opportunities to move from one unionized position to another are limited. Even when such moves are possible, the wage structures in unionized workplaces are typically tied to seniority, making it difficult to achieve significant pay increases by switching jobs.
For union members, wage increases depend on collective bargaining. Contracts, which typically last three to five years in Canada, lock in wage rates for the duration of the agreement. Workers whose contracts were negotiated just before or during the early stages of the cost-of-living crisis have seen their real wages stagnate or decline as inflation eroded their purchasing power.

title: Not Just Vibes: Unionized Workers Are Feeling Real Wage Losses
section: Private sector union wages are treading water
text:
Private sector union wages are treading water
For union members, wage increases depend on collective bargaining – which ultimately depends on the right to strike. Contracts, which typically last three to five years in Canada, lock in wage rates for the duration of the agreement. Workers whose contracts were negotiated just before or during the early stages of the cost-of-living crisis in 2020-2021 have seen their real wages stagnate or decline as inflation eroded their purchasing power.
A closer look at the data for private sector union members reveals the extent of the stagnation. The chart underneath shows average wages for private sector union members or those that are covered by a CA by each quintile of hourly earnings.
While unionized workers in the lowest wage quintile saw some gains—an $1.75 increase (+11%) over the past decade—most others have seen little to no growth when accounting for inflation. Across most earnings levels, private sector union wages have barely moved, leaving workers no better off than a decade ago – and wondering when their pay will reflect the broader trend of wage growth.







The Coming Battle for Fair Wages
The silver lining for private sector union members is that change may be on the horizon. As pre-cost-of-living crisis contracts expire and new agreements are negotiated, workers and their unions will likely push for significant raises to make up for lost ground. After a decade of treading water, the demand for better pay will be stronger than ever.
Canadian union members can look to the example set by the United Auto Workers (UAW) in the United States. In a highly strategic and combative campaign, the UAW recently secured a 25% wage increase over four years—an impressive victory after decades of uphill struggle.
If Canadian unions take a similarly bold and strategic approach, the next wave of collective bargaining could bring long-overdue gains for unionized workers, restoring the wage premium they have historically enjoyed.

title: Not Just Vibes: Union Members Face Wage Stagnation
text:
Economic growth is back on track, inflation is easing, and real wages have finally grown. This has led some policymakers to suggest that the cost-of-living crisis is fading. Economists now ensure us that “the economy” is doing pretty well, all things considered.
Despite this “good news” there is a prevalent mood of anger and frustration due to financial pain. How can real wages be rising, while most people perceive a rapid decline in their living standards? Some commentators have insisted that the economic perceptions of most people are just out of sync with reality. Some people just don’t know how good they really have it, right?
There are many reasons to be skeptical about this narrative, but we can start with a simple one – large groups of workers have so far been left out of the alleged wage recovery.
It is true that many workers have recently seen significant wage gains after years of stagnation. According to Labour Force Survey data, average hourly real wages (adjusted to 2024 dollars based on the all-items CPI) grew by $2.58 for men (+7.4%) and $2.88 for women (+9.7%) over the last decade. Most of these gains came in the past two years.

title: Not Just Vibes: Union Members Face Wage Stagnation
section: Union members, nearly a third of workers, are being left behind
text:
Union members, nearly a third of workers, are being left behind
While many workers are seeing their wages grow, union members are notably missing out. Most have experienced stagnant or even declining real wages. The chart below shows average wages for non-union workers compared to those who are either union members or are covered by a collective agreement.
In the private sector, unionized workers saw their hourly wages increase by a meager 30 cents (+0.9%) from 2014 to 2024. Public sector union members fared even worse, with real hourly wages dropping by 94 cents an hour (-2.3%) over the same period.
By contrast, non-unionized workers have seen substantial wage growth. In the private sector, non-union employees enjoyed an impressive $4.15 (+14.2%) increase in hourly pay. Non-union public sector workers, primarily professionals and managers that are already highly paid, experienced more modest gains of $1.12 (+2.7%).
Historically, private sector union members earned higher average wages than their non-unionized peers. But since the onset of the cost-of-living crisis in 2021-22, that advantage has eroded. Today, average wages for non-unionized workers exceed those of unionized workers by about 40 cents per hour.
In 2024, there were over 3.3 million union members in the public sector and another 2 million in the private sector – that’s about three in ten paid employees in the country who have largely been left behind as wages rise.
Why are union members, long known for securing better wages, falling behind during this period of historic wage growth?







One major factor is job-switching. Much of the wage growth among non-unionized private sector workers has been driven by employees leaving low-paying jobs for higher-paying opportunities. Given the higher than usual labour demand as the economy re-opened – pandemic be damned – from late 2021 to 2023, employers also had to offer higher wages to attract new hires, especially in very low-wage, front-line industries. This path to higher earnings isn’t as available to union members.
Unionized jobs, particularly in the private sector, are relatively scarce. Opportunities to move from one unionized position to another are limited. Even when such moves are possible, the wage structures in unionized workplaces are typically tied to seniority, making it difficult to achieve immediate pay increases by switching jobs.

title: Not Just Vibes: Union Members Face Wage Stagnation
section: Private sector union wages are treading water
text:
Private sector union wages are treading water
For union members, wage increases depend on collective bargaining – which ultimately depends on the right to strike. Contracts, which typically last three to five years in Canada, lock in wage rates for the duration of the agreement. Workers whose contracts were negotiated just before or during the early stages of the cost-of-living crisis in 2020-2021 have seen their real wages stagnate or decline as inflation eroded their purchasing power.
A closer look at the data for private sector union members reveals the extent of the stagnation. The chart underneath shows average wages for private sector union members or those that are covered by a CA by each quintile of hourly earnings.
While unionized workers in the lowest wage quintile saw some gains—an $1.75 increase (+11%) over the past decade—most others have seen little to no growth when accounting for inflation. Across most earnings levels, private sector union wages have barely moved, leaving most workers no better off than a decade ago – and wondering when their pay will reflect the broader trend of wage growth.







The Coming Battle for Fair Wages
The silver lining for private sector union members is that change may be on the horizon. As pre-cost-of-living crisis contracts expire and new agreements are negotiated, workers and their unions will likely push for significant raises to make up for lost ground. After a decade of treading water, the demand for major raises that restore lost purchasing power will be stronger than ever.
Canadian union members are already looking to the example set by the United Auto Workers (UAW) in the United States. In a highly strategic and combative campaign, the UAW recently secured a 25% wage increase over four years—an impressive victory after decades of uphill struggle.
If Canadian unions take a similarly bold and strategic approach, the next wave of collective bargaining could bring long-overdue gains for unionized workers, restoring the wage premium they have historically enjoyed.

title: How Unions Boost Pay Where It Matters Most
text:

Yet despite what average wage data might suggest, unions still confer a higher paycheck for most workers, especially those in lower-wage or non-standard employment.

title: How Unions Boost Pay Where It Matters Most
section: Unions are busting inequality in the public sector
text:
Unions are busting inequality in the public sector
A similar pattern is evident in the public sector, where average wages are about $3 higher per hour for non-union members. Unlike in the private sector, this has been a long-standing trend.
One reason for this is that higher union density rates in public sector workplaces mean membership more clearly separates average workers from highly paid professionals and managers (p. 19). Another reason is that unionized public sector workers have endured wage stagnation due to significant government attacks on their right to bargain and strike. Managers and many professionals, by contrast, face no such constraints.
The average union vs. non-union wage differential is largely driven by workers in highly paid professional occupations in the public sector—lawyers, engineers, and finance and health professionals, except nurses.







As in the private sector, union members enjoy higher average wages throughout the bottom of the wage distribution. Union members had higher wages in 15 out of 23 (65%) occupations with lower-than-average wages for the public sector. This pattern—high union density that boosts wages most at the low end—likely contributes to the inequality-reducing effects of public sector employment in Canada.

title: How Unions Boost Pay Where It Matters Most
section: Protecting the paychecks of precarious workers
text:
Protecting the paychecks of precarious workers
Finally, we can examine the effect of union membership with regard to employment status, which is one of the most important factors behind low pay. Workers outside the standard employment contract—such as involuntary part-timers, temporary workers, and multiple job holders—have much lower average wages.
Union membership largely protects against the corrosive effects of non-standard work arrangements on wages and working conditions. Workers in non-standard employment situations had average wages that were over $8 an hour higher (+32%) than their non-union counterparts.

title: How Unions Boost Pay Where It Matters Most
section: Unions: So worth it, you’ll live longer
text:
Unions: So worth it, you’ll live longer
So, is it still worth it to unionize? Absolutely. Most workers—those who are not managers or highly paid professionals—can expect to enjoy higher wages if they are part of a union. In the years to come, it is likely that unionized workers will secure significant raises as pre-inflation crisis contracts expire and new agreements are signed in a high wage growth environment.
And this is only considering hourly wages. It does not account for other forms of compensation, such as pension contributions or access to health insurance plans. Beyond dollars and cents, unions improve members’ lives both at work—through better job security and protection against employer abuse—and outside of work, where studies show union membership leads to better well-being and even extends life expectancy.

title: Dashboard: A data portrait of union density in Canada
text:
One of the main measures of the health of a country’s labour movement and the level of respect for labour rights, is union density – simply, the rate of employees that are members of labour unions. Generally, the higher the rate of unionization, the better it is for workers.
Statistics Canada produces some official estimates of union density based on the Labour Force Survey (LFS). One can find, for example, official union density estimates by education level, occupation, or industry. There is an issue using those estimates to draw conclusions about unionization patterns in Canada – is it in the private or public sector?
Unionization rates are about five times higher in the public sector (76%) than in the private sector (15%), meaning patterns and trends vary greatly by sector. For example, what is average union density in the transportation and warehousing industries in Canada? According to the official estimates, about 40.7% of those workers were unionized in 2023. Yet if we break that down into sector, we see that 82% in the public sector are union members, while only 25% of those in the private sector are.
Since union rates are always high in one sector and low in another, averages needs to be disaggregated by sector to make sense of the trends in the data. Yet none of StatCan’s official estimate tables are available broken down by sector. It’s possible to pay for a custom tabulation. But to otherwise access that information for free requires using microdata files that demand some level of proficiency with statistical or coding software.
To make this open-access data more accessible, I have created an interactive dashboard featuring Canadian union density data from 2006 until (currently) October of 2024. I plan to add live-update capacity in the future to refresh the charts with new LFS data as it is released.
The dashboard has charts and tables on union density for 15 variables, always broken down into the public and private sectors, including:

Age
Gender
Employment status
Industry
Occupation
Province and CMA
Job tenure
And more!

For the time being, these values are presented without any measures of estimate quality, like the coefficient of variation or confidence intervals. Producing those estimates from PUMF is a major project unto itself, so maybe some day, but for now these values are presented as is and should be used with caution.



Union density has been defined in slightly different ways. title: Dashboard: A data portrait of union density in Canada
text:
One of the main measures of the health of a country’s labour movement and the level of respect for labour rights, is union density – simply, the rate of employees that are members of labour unions. Generally, the higher the rate of unionization, the better it is for workers.
Statistics Canada produces some official estimates of union density based on the Labour Force Survey (LFS). One can find, for example, official union density estimates by education level, occupation, or industry. There is an issue using those estimates to draw conclusions about unionization patterns in Canada – is it in the private or public sector?
Unionization rates are about five times higher in the public sector (76%) than in the private sector (15%), meaning patterns and trends vary greatly by sector. For example, what is average union density in the transportation and warehousing industries in Canada? According to the official estimates, about 40.7% of those workers were unionized in 2023. Yet if we break that down into sector, we see that 82% in the public sector are union members, while only 25% of those in the private sector are.
Since union rates are always high in one sector and low in another, averages needs to be disaggregated by sector to make sense of the trends in the data. Yet none of StatCan’s official estimate tables are available broken down by sector. It’s possible to pay for a custom tabulation. But to otherwise access that information for free requires using microdata files that demand some level of proficiency with statistical or coding software.
To make this open-access data more accessible, I have created an interactive dashboard featuring Canadian union density data from 2006 until (currently) October of 2024. I plan to add live-update capacity in the future to refresh the charts with new LFS data as it is released.
The dashboard has charts and tables on union density for 15 variables, always broken down into the public and private sectors, including:

Age

title: Half a Billion Hours for Free: The Role of Unions in Fighting Unpaid Overtime
text:
Wage theft is a deeply entrenched problem in Canada and unpaid overtime stands out as one of its most egregious forms. Every year, millions of workers in Canada perform hundreds of millions of hours of work for free. Many employers, and even entire industries, have come to depend on this free labour. One of the most effective defenses workers have against this exploitation is joining a union.
Employers are legally required to pay employees for all work performed under contract, but unpaid overtime is everywhere in the Canadian economy. Once workers exceed regular full-time hours, unpaid labour becomes routine – so common it’s treated as normal and expected.
Unpaid overtime is officially illegal, yet it remains widespread. Although the details vary, provincial and federal labour standards generally prohibit employers from (1) not paying their employees for overtime or (2) not paying them the required overtime rates.
Yet, nearly half of all overtime hours worked in Canada are unpaid. Employers rarely face serious consequences for compelling their employees to work for free. Even when action is taken, such as in recent banking industry settlements, legal processes are often very lengthy and expensive, favoring large corporations over workers.
Employees, on the other hand, often face reprisals for refusing unpaid overtime. In many workplaces, there is an unspoken pressure to work unpaid hours to maintain career advancement opportunities. Many workers feel they have no choice but to comply with this ultra-exploitative practice.

Unpaid work. Bosses love it and are mostly free to violate the law to get it. Entire industries and vital public services depend on it. Can workers do anything to turn the tables? title: Post title on overtimes
section: A thought experiment on the value of union protection
text:
A thought experiment on the value of union protection
Let’s try a simple thought experiment to roughly quantify the value of extending this protection against free labour to all workers. What if, all other things being equal, employers had to pay non-union members for their overtime work at the same rate that union members. That means in the private sector, workers were paid for 88.6% of their overtime hours instead of just half, while those the public sector would be paid for 50% instead of 20% of their overtime.

Private sector
In the private sector, about 1.5 million non-unionized workers did 542 million hours of overtime total. Their bosses only paid them for half, which worked out to 281 million hours. If we assume that workers are paid the standard overtime rate of 1.5 times that works out to an average of $63 per hour, resulting in an overtime wage bill of $17.6B or about $11,700 per worker.
If they had the same incidence of paid overtime as union members? They would have been paid for 480 million hours instead, which would have worked out to $30.3 billion in wages or $20,000 per worker. That would be an aggregate wage increase of $13.1B or an additional $8,733 in overtime pay per worker.
We can also do those calculations the other way around. What would happen to the overtime pay of union members if they had no protection against unpaid overtime? In this situation, they would only have been paid for 72.5 (50%) out of 144 million hours, leading to total overtime pay of just $3.98 billion – a decline of $3 billion or $11,320 per worker without unions.


Public sector
In the public sector, the distinction was less extreme. If non-union workers had the same rate of paid overtime as union members, they would have been paid for 33 million (50%) instead of 13 million hours of overtime (21%), leading to a wage bump of $1.6 billion.
On the other hand, if public sector union members were paid for their extra work like non-members, they would only have been paid for 48.5 million, instead of 117 million hours of overtime. As a result, their overtime wages would shrink to 3.19 billion – that’s a drop of $4.6 billion or $7,050 per worker.

But bosses have become dependent on this free lunch taken from workers. They will say that they can’t go without it.
From January to October of the year, over 454 million hours of unpaid labour were worked. Pro-rated to the remainder of the year, let’s assume 544 million hours. In the private sector, that free labour is going directly to bolster the profits of business owners. While in the public sector, austerity-driven governments have taken to squeezing as much free work out of public servants as possible to facilitate budget cuts and under-spending.

title: Title on taxes
text:
Canada’s tax system is notoriously unfair. At every twist and turn, it is set up to favour those who make their income just by owning property, rather than those who must work for wages. One of the most stunning examples of this bias toward property income is the capital gains exemption loophole.
Capital gains are profits made by selling assets that have increased in value. If one buys company shares worth $10,000 and sells them down the road for $20,000, that’s a capital gain of $10,000. Most people own little to no capital assets and so enjoy significant capital gains only very rarely – it is mostly the territory of the wealthy and corporations, who buy and sell assets for gain with regularity.
Since 2003, only 50% of income made by capital gains has been subjected to taxes – that is to say that half of capital gains were entirely tax free. Income paid to labour or some transfers like EI payments are always entirely subject to income taxes. Yet, if you are a landlord, and just sold your third investment property for a hefty return – half of that income would be totally tax free.
Tax justice advocates have long called for closing this capital gains tax loophole, which is set up to massively benefit wealthy property owners and corporations. Canada’s Liberal government, under pressure to pursue some kind of tax reform, both to comply with OECD-wide tax changes and to fund their own spending agenda, announced intent to raise the rate of inclusion on capital gains over $250,000 from 50 to 66% early in 2024. This amounts to a very small effective increase in capital gains tax rates, which are still extremely generous.
Under the new tax plan, the 50% inclusion rate still applies to gains of under a quarter million dollars, while the new rate of two-thirds applies on gains over that threshold. In other words, a very large portion of that income is still completely tax free. Since the threshold for the new tax rate is so high, only a very small number of high income individuals would be impacted. Businesses would have their gains taxed entirely at the higher rate, but it was coupled with some rather generous tax benefits to small and medium sized businesses to offset much of the impact.

text:
Header on productivity
Labour productivity, the measure of how much value is produced by an hour of labour or by each worker employed, is more directly related to well-being than GDP and GDP growth. It is no coincidence that countries with the highest standards of living in the world also tend to be the most productive – it is a necessary, but not a sufficient condition for prosperity.
The chart below compares the average top personal CGT rate on the horizontal axis to average labour productivity on the vertical axis, across each time period. There is a clear positive correlation between capital gains taxes and labour productivity, where more productive countries tend to tax capital gains at higher rates and vice versa.
Such a finding concurs with a growing body of research demonstrating that as national economies mature and grow more productive, they also tend to tax capital income in general at higher rates. Researchers at the Centre for Analysis of Taxation found that in the United Kingdom, found that overly generous CGT rates negatively impacted labour productivity by encouraging people to work in low-productivity, solo-proprietorship businesses:

Currently capital gains are taxed at much lower rates than income. This encourages individuals to work in a form that allows them to be paid in capital gains, for example setting up a personal service company through which they get paid, and later extracting the income as capital gains by liquidating the company.
A negative side effect of low CGT rates is the proliferation of these businesses, which not only reduce the overall tax take, but hamper productivity by having people working in ways that are less efficient but are individually optimal because of the tax saving. This contributes to the regularly diagnosed ‘long tail’ of unproductive firms in the UK. (p. 2)

While the UK has had especially permissive laws and regulations on these forms of income-shifting, the tax incentive to shift labour income into capital income by solo-incorporation remains strong in Canada (p. 22), even though personal service corporations receive less favourable tax treatment than in the UK. It is widely recognized by experts that Canada’s economy is overly reliant on small enterprises that are naturally less productive due to economies of scale. Could our permissive capital gains taxation system be contributing to this problem?
Other researchers have suggested additional ways capital income taxation can improve labour productivity. The first is that raising the share of tax revenue from capital presents an opportunity to lower the relative tax burden on labour, which is known to have a distortionary impact on productivity. Second, is that raising more revenue from capital affords an opportunity to raise government spending in areas that are known to improve productivity.

text:
Header on the moment
Despite the collective meltdown by Canada’s capitalist class and it’s various representatives throughout society over the very minor tax increase, the reform looked like it was a done deal in the summer of 2024. In a baffling turn of events, the ailing Liberals pulled the capital gains tax reform out into a separate bill, instead of passing it with the budget as tax measures usually are.

They missed the moment not only because they scored an own-goal at the very last second, but because their proposals – focus-group tested “progressive” on one hand and austerity-hawk neoliberal on the other – were far too modest and limited in vision to begin with.
The new rate of two-thirds falls far short of even Canada’s historical high, when in the 1990s three-quarters (75%) of capital gains were included in taxable income. To fix Canada’s regressive tax system, it is essential that income on capital and property is treated like income on labour, meaning all of it is subject to taxation.
Now, the fate of the small step forward to tax justice looks grim. There is an all out regressive taxation propaganda blitz to ensure that the changes are buried by the next government. We will hear even more about how unfair these changes really are. About how very modest efforts to raise taxes on high incomes and corporate profits are causing Canada’s economic problems. How innovation and productivity will be crushed.
Now the Liberals are turning against their own tax reform in a futile attempt to bail water from a sinking ship. Former finance minister Chrystia Freeland, entirely unable to defend her own signature tax policy, has now promised to scrap it if elected. Former central banker and notable man of the people, Mark Carney, has done the same.
It will go much further than killing the capital gains tax reform, as a foot in the door making way for an even more regressive tax system, making Canada an vastly more unequal society than it already is.
Data from two dozen European countries shows that, at least in mature industrial economies, having higher capital gains tax rates, which are likely indicative of higher rates of capital income tax in general, is linked to higher labour productivity, lower inequality, and higher spending priority on essential social services like health and education.

title: Title on taxes
section: Higher gains tax rates, higher productivity
text:
Higher gains tax rates, higher productivity
Labour productivity, the measure of how much value is produced by an hour of labour or by each worker employed, is more directly related to well-being than GDP and GDP growth. It is no coincidence that countries with the highest standards of living in the world also tend to be the most productive – it is a necessary, but not a sufficient condition for prosperity.
More productive countries tend to tax capital gains at higher rates. In the past, I have written about how Canada’s capital gains inclusion rate has little bearing on productivity growth. Yet, when looking at an international dataset of industrial economies, there is a clear association between the level of productivity achieved by an economy and the CGT rate.
The chart below compares the average top personal CGT rate on the horizontal axis to average labour productivity on the vertical axis, across each time period.1 There is a clear positive correlation between capital gains taxes and labour productivity, where more productive countries tend to tax capital gains at higher rates and vice versa.2
Such a finding concurs with research demonstrating that as economies industrialize, mature and grow more productive, they also tend to tax capital income at higher rates.








How are capital gains tax rates connected to labour productivity?
What is the connection between capital gains tax rates and productivity? We have heard ad nauseum about how even a modest increase in capital gains taxes will destroy productivity and crater Canada’s economy.
If that is the case, why are the most productive countries also the ones that tax capital gains – and capital in general – at the highest rates?

Promoting proliferation of small businesses
Researchers at the Centre for Analysis of Taxation found that in the United Kingdom, found that overly generous CGT rates negatively impacted labour productivity by encouraging people to work in low-productivity, small and solo-proprietorship businesses in order to gain tax advantages:

Currently capital gains are taxed at much lower rates than income. This encourages individuals to work in a form that allows them to be paid in capital gains, for example setting up a personal service company through which they get paid, and later extracting the income as capital gains by liquidating the company.
A negative side effect of low CGT rates is the proliferation of these businesses, which not only reduce the overall tax take, but hamper productivity by having people working in ways that are less efficient but are individually optimal because of the tax saving. This contributes to the regularly diagnosed ‘long tail’ of unproductive firms in the UK. (p. 2)

While the UK has had especially permissive laws and regulations on these forms of income-shifting, the tax incentive to shift labour income into capital income by solo or small business incorporation remains strong in Canada (p. 22), even though personal service corporations receive less favourable tax treatment than in the UK.
Firm size and productivity are intuitively linked by economy of scale. Larger firms have a natural productivity advantage over smaller firms due to the efficiency increases of economies of scale – they can access much more capital, invest in more machinery and IP, hire more workers, and build larger facilities for them to work at. For that reason, the most productive industries tend to be the domain of large firms and vice versa.
It is widely recognized that workers in Canada are less productive on average than some peer countries, notably the U.S., due to our relative over reliance on small enterprises.
Canada’s tax system has an unusually generous treatment of capital gains, especially when small and medium sized businesses are involved, which one tax researcher describes as an “endless gateway to tax-minimizing and economy distorting stratagems.” It is reasonable to hypothesize that the Canadian tax system’s preference for capital gains could be contributing to this problem by encouraging the proliferation of small incorporated businesses.


Incentivizing productivity-killing financial speculation
When a business invests into producing goods and services for sale, we can consider that a productive activity that fulfills some social use. To profit in this way requires the exploitation of workers, but that is besides the point here, which is that these activities produce wealth in the form of real goods and services.
However, investors can find many ways to make a profit. Financial or speculative activities can be immensely profitable, but only involve assets being exchanged between parties, for example, stock or currency trading. When an asset is sold at a higher price than it was bought for, that is a capital gain – the profit is purely financial because nothing of value has been produced, only changed hands.
A lax and overly generous system of capital gains taxation therefore directly incentivizes zero-productivity speculative activity, which often stems from low-productivity sectors like construction. Research done by Canadians for Tax Fairness has shown that the 50% capital gains loophole has helped blow up the housing bubble and driven rents up by encouraging the financialization of housing with tremendous tax savings on the sale of investment properties.
Surely, the Canadian economy’s reliance on a housing bubble has been worsened by the tax system’s strong preference for capital gains – as investment properties are flipped after a few years of surging prices – which in turn has dragged on productivity.
In demographic terms, much of Canada’s former manufacturing workforce, mostly men with high school or college level education, has shifted into residential and commercial construction.
Labour productivity levels has been low and stagnant for over 40 years in the construction sector for many reasons. One widely recognized reason for construction’s productivity problem is the highly fragmentary nature of the sector, which is composed mostly of very small, low productivity firms that pay low wages.


Offsetting labour taxes and funding public investment
A higher capital gains tax regime could also impact productivity in positive ways. The first is that raising the share of tax revenue from capital presents an opportunity to lower the relative tax burden on labour, which can negatively impact productivity.
Excessive taxation of labour income can reduce aggregate demand, which can harm productivity because it “reduces the market size for new innovations and has an adverse effect on domestic rates of innovation” (p. 3). By alleviating the tax burden on the working class majority of people, the general pool of money (and credit) available for (mostly) spending, but also saving and investing rises.
Capital gains taxation can have another positive impact on productivity, in that raising more revenue from capital affords an opportunity to raise government spending without adding to the tax burden on labour income (p. 4).
While much economic theory treats government spending and taxation as only an economic negative, it is crystal clear that spending in certain areas can potentially enhance labour productivity. In economic terms, this is described as the distinction between productive and unproductive government spending.
Research has found that by improving the health, well-being, and skill level of the workforce, state expenditures in areas such as such as education, and health care can increase the amount of value produced by workers. Likewise, investments into infrastructure and public goods can also enhance labour productivity.
Another obvious productivity boosting avenue of spending would be government spending on research, development, innovation, and promoting the widespread adoption of new technologies. This is an area of public investment that both levels of Canadian governments have been lagging behind for a long time.

section: Higher gains tax rates, lower inequality
text:
Higher gains tax rates, lower inequality
There is yet another pathway for capital gains taxation to impact labour productivity – social and economic inequality. Experts widely conclude that productivity and economic inequality are intrinsically linked in what is often called the Inclusivity (or Inequality)-Productivity Nexus.
In general, workers in societies that are more equal grow more productive, while rising inequality can have a dampening effect on productivity growth. Researchers at the OECD found that the relationship is based on how inequality is both caused by and drives labour market outcomes at the bottom of the income distribution:

The main link is via high income inequalities reducing investments in human capital, which in turn lead to diminished prospects for productivity growth. Hence … a strong emphasis is put on the impact of poverty and inequality of opportunity on growth.

Below the chart displays the connection between income inequality – measured as the share of income captured by the top 10% – and the top personal capital gains tax rate for countries in the dataset. As expected, countries that are more equal in income terms have higher CGT rate than less equal countries and vice versa.







The connection between capital gains tax rates and economic inequality more intuitive than with productivity. Regressive tax systems are usually that way because they give very favourable treatment to capital income compared to labour income. Income from owning and selling property is vital to those on top of the class hierarchy, while the vast majority of people own no capital assets to sell in the first place and so seldom have significant capital gains ever.
Higher capital gains taxes could directly contribute to reducing inequality by taxing a preferred source of typically low-tax income for very wealthy people and large corporations, then using that to invest in public services and public goods that reduce inequality.
It is very likely that countries with higher CGT rates tax higher income at higher rates and are less permissive with high income tax filers – in other words, it is one marker for having a more progressive overall tax system.

title: Title on taxes
section: Higher gains tax rates, more priority on social spending
text:
Higher gains tax rates, more priority on social spending
Taxes are a tool to raise revenue. How the funds that are raised with taxes are spent is also important to consider. There is a well-known connection between a government’s ability to raise revenue (taxes as a share of GDP) and economic growth, with increased tax revenue supporting higher government social spending.
Research has established a connection between government tax revenue and both healthcare and education spending. Mostly this has been studied in low and middle income countries in the context of development, but we can see something like this relationship on display in industrialized, European economies as well.
Capital gains tax rates were strongly related to government expenditures on health, education, and social protection (e.g. social security payments) relative to gross domestic product. Countries that had higher CGT rates – countries that tend to be both more equal and productive – also display a higher priority on social expenditures that support the health and wellness of the population.







Public spending in areas like health, education, and social security or income support have a well-known re-distributional effect, resulting in reduced income and wealth inequality. Countries with higher tax rates had more progressive tax systems overall, and were more likely to use the revenue raised pro-social ends – and not things like paying for extremely regressive tax breaks for the rich.

A note on zero gains countries
There are a small number of countries in the sample that do not tax capital gains at all, including Belgium, the Czech Republic, Luxembourg, Slovakia, Slovenia, and Switzerland. In the scatter plots above, those countries have not been included because they stand apart from the general trend in terms of their zero tax rate.
It is likely more appropriate to compare those zero rate countries as a group to countries that do tax gains. Below, the table shows the average measures used above for countries with a zero rate of capital gains tax versus all other countries.
Among countries that didn’t tax capital gains at all, there were two high productivity (Belgium and Switzerland), and two low productivity countries (Slovakia and Slovenia), and one with productivity data so cooked, it isn’t worth considering (Luxembourg).







At first glance, the zero rate countries are vastly more productive, but this is mostly illusory, due to Luxembourg’s vastly over-inflated productivity statistics bringing up the average.3 Account for that fact and productivity levels are equivalent in the 2011-2012 period, while zero rate countries end up slightly more productive, due to very strong growth by Belgium and Switzerland.
As we might expect from our findings so far, countries that do not tax capital gains saw a higher share of income going to the top 10% of income takers in the country compared to those that did tax capital gains. Likewise, the zero rate countries had a much smaller share of social spending in GDP, indicating a lower priority on government spending that reduces poverty and improves health and well-being.

title: Title on taxes
text:
Canada’s tax system is notoriously unfair. At every twist and turn, it is set up to favour those who make their income just by owning property, rather than those who must work for wages. One of the most stunning examples of this bias toward property income is the capital gains exemption loophole.
Capital gains are profits made by selling assets that have increased in value. If one buys company shares worth $10,000 and sells them down the road for $20,000, that’s a capital gain of $10,000. Most people own little to no capital assets and so enjoy significant capital gains only very rarely – it is mostly the territory of the wealthy and corporations, who buy and sell assets for gain with regularity.
Since 2003, only 50% of income made by capital gains has been subjected to taxes – that is to say that half of capital gains were entirely tax free. Income paid to labour or some transfers like EI payments are always entirely subject to income taxes. Yet, if you are a landlord, and just sold your third investment property for a hefty return – half of that income would be totally tax free.
Tax justice advocates have long called for closing this capital gains tax loophole, which is set up to massively benefit wealthy property owners and corporations. Canada’s Liberal government, under pressure to pursue some kind of tax reform, both to comply with OECD-wide tax changes and to fund their own spending agenda, announced intent to raise the rate of inclusion on capital gains over $250,000 from 50 to 66% early in 2024. This amounts to a very small effective increase in capital gains tax rates, which are still extremely generous.
Under the new tax plan, the 50% inclusion rate still applies to gains of under a quarter million dollars, while the new rate of two-thirds applies on gains over that threshold. In other words, a very large portion of that income is still completely tax free. Since the threshold for the new tax rate is so high, only a very small number of high income individuals would be impacted. Businesses would have their gains taxed entirely at the higher rate, but it was coupled with some rather generous tax benefits to small and medium sized businesses to offset much of the impact.

text:
It’s not a “vibecession.” Canadians are really struggling more, and the data proves it. Politicians are trying to convince us that things are actually great in the economy. They’re not. ______________ Ryan Romard
Affordability discontent dominates Canada’s political and economic landscape—it was rated the top issue in politics as we rang in 2024 and remained in the lead throughout the year. Yet, GDP growth has exceeded expectations and average wages finally grew enough to outpace the general rise in prices during peak inflation.
How can we square this widespread anguish with seemingly positive economic indicators? Many commentators have mistakenly concluded that the source of this frustration is psychological, that common perceptions of the economy are just out of sync with the big-picture reality. They’ve even made a term for it—the so-called vibecession. The economy is doing well, they say—people are just upset because the “vibes” are off.
To people who advocate this perspective, the dominant mood is purely political, reflecting the success of right-wing populist rhetoric rather than concrete economic conditions. Those dismissive critics are missing the big picture.

section: Measuring income that people can actually spend
text:
Measuring income that people can actually spend
First, we should look at a fuller measure of income that reflects how much is actually available for spending, rather than simply wage data. When we talk about disposable income, it means the amount of total income that remains after government transfers are received and taxes are paid. 
It’s vital to consider income from all sources, not just wages, but also things like pension payments, self-employment, and crucially, investment and property income.Using the concept of total income, we can account for the unique role of debt in shaping household finances. 
In accounting terms, most household expenses, on things like groceries or rent, are counted as consumption expenditures. Interest payments on credit card, mortgage, educational, and other debts are treated differently, as a one-way financial drain that reduces income available for spending. If you had an income of $3,500 in a month, but interest payments on your mortgage and credit card ate up $500, it is as though you only had $3,000 to spend to begin with. 
One reason for treating debt this way is that it is a two-way street. Households can also receive debt payments. For example, investors that own debt equity as an asset, like corporate or government bonds, regularly receive a return on it in the form of interest payments. At the very top of the income and wealth hierarchy, households commonly receive more of such investment income than they pay out as interest on their own debts. 
This dynamic is key to understanding why so many people are still struggling despite cooling inflation and rising real wages.

section: Rising interest rates are squeezing households–as intended
text:
Rising interest rates are squeezing households–as intended
For decades, low interest rates kept the burden of debt repayment in check. Since the cost of living crisis accelerated with the increased inflation levels of 2021-2022, people have relied more on debt to fund their consumption. At the same time, the once very manageable costs of holding debt have surged to levels not seen in over 30 years.
Below, the chart shows the share of disposable income that is taken up just by interest payments on debts, broken down by income quintile. Across all income levels, the share of household disposable income devoted to interest payments on debt increased substantially since the start of 2020.
At the start of 2020, interest payments on debts—such as credit card, line of credit, or mortgage loans—took up an average of about 6 per cent of household disposable income. By the summer of 2024, that figure had nearly doubled to 11.6 per cent. The impact of debt grows more intense as household income gets lower—it’s especially punishing on the poorest quintile of households, who are paying nearly 20 per cent of their disposable income on interest payments alone.






The rapidly growing pain of debt is the intended consequence of the Bank of Canada’s ill-advised inflation busting strategy, cranking up interest rates to “cool” the economy. It has also made income inequality much worse. Most people are feeling the sting of rising interest rates. However, many high-income households have gained overall from increased investment returns on financial assets due to higher interest rates.
In accounting terms, most household expenses, on things like groceries or rent, are counted as consumption expenditures—spending that buys real goods and services. Interest payments on debts are treated differently—as a one-way financial drain that reduces income available for spending on anything else.

section: Energy, food and shelter are neck-and-neck with growing wages
text:
Energy, food and shelter are neck-and-neck with growing wages
When most economists adjust wage data to inflation, they account for price changes using an “all-items” Consumer Price Index (CPI) that represents a typical basket of goods and services. This broad measure fails to capture disproportionate price changes in necessities that consumers feel more directly.
Since the start of 2018, average nominal hourly wages have grown by just under 30 per cent, while the all-items CPI grew by 22.3 per cent. Does this mean that wages have finally beaten inflation? Not exactly. While wage growth outpaced the broad CPI, essentials like energy and food saw sharper price increases, hitting lower-income households hardest.
The cost-of-living crisis is driven by significant price increases in a few key products, which have kept pace with wage growth even as the all-items CPI slowed. From the start of 2018 to the fall of 2024, price growth for energy outran the all-items measure by two per cent, shelter by 9.1 per cent, and food by 9.2 per cent. Meanwhile, mortgage interest costs have surged by a staggering 46.8 per cent, putting home owners under immense pressure to keep up.

text:
The growing burden of covering basic needs
If real wages are finally recovering from the worst of the inflationary crisis, why are so many people still struggling to make ends meet? The heart of the matter is that households are forced to spend a larger share of their disposable income on essentials compared to a few years ago.
The chart below depicts average household spending as a share of household disposable income. To account for income inequality, Statistics Canada has broken the data down by income quintile, meaning five equally sized groups of households from the lowest to highest incomes.
Spending has been broken down into expenditures to meet basic needs (including housing, water, energy, food and non-alcoholic beverages) and all other goods and services. The share of income taken up by basic needs has grown for all households but those at the very top of the income hierarchy.
For households in the lowest fifth of incomes, spending on necessities rose by over 11.3 per cent, consuming nearly all of their disposable income—a deeply troubling indicator. Households in the second (5.8 per cent), third (2.2 per cent) and fourth (2.4 per cent) quintiles also experienced a rising share of income going toward necessities, with basic needs consuming between 55 and 39 per cent of their disposable income.






People in three of five income quintiles spent over 100 per cent of their disposable income in total, indicating debt-financed consumption. On the other hand, high income households were spending a bit less of their total disposable income than five years ago, meaning they have more discretionary income to spend, save, or invest at the end of the month.
How can we explain this trend? There are two factors working together to squeeze household finances for the majority of people. The first is the most obvious, because we notice it every time we shop for groceries—prices for staple goods have grown right alongside wages, even as overall inflation falls. Energy, food and shelter are neck-and-neck with growing wages

section: We need a real plan for social and economic justice
text:
We need a real plan for social and economic justice
The affordability crisis isn’t merely a matter of perception—most households are losing financial ground to debt and the high cost of living. If we are to rise to the moment, we need bold, transformative policy responses—the likes of which are seldom on offer from the political status quo.
Commit to using the power of the Canadian government to forbid corporate price gouging with price controls and tax back windfall corporate profits. It would surely work better than trying to shame corporate executives into lowering prices by bringing them in front of Parliament and asking them stern questions without follow-up.
Burst the housing bubble with strong rent controls and massive build-outs of non-market and co-operative housing, not market-based approaches that only drive prices up.
Transform Canada’s food system by breaking up corporate food sector oligopolies and providing public-sector options in the grocery sector, rather than with toothless, voluntary codes of corporate conduct.
Extend the principles of universality in all vital areas of healthcare including dental, drugs, and mental health, instead of limited, means-tested programs that can be more easily trashed by an incoming government. Instead of one-time payments to all regardless of need, revitalize income support systems to ensure that nobody ever lives in legislated poverty in Canada ever again.
Cancel all student debts and create stable public funding for post-secondary systems so that tuition can be dramatically lowered and eventually eliminated.
Those were just a few suggestions of what an agenda capable of fighting back against right-wing populism that plays on people’s justified anger and frustration could look like. Real change won’t happen without a mass movement to confront entrenched wealth and corporate power head-on—a movement that many disaffected people who are hungry for a real alternative would be eager to join.

Closing header

Header
The capital gains tax exemption is one of the most regressive and expensive tax loopholes in Canada. It is in effect, a gift from the Canadian government – and the tax paying public by extension – to corporations and the wealthiest people in society.
In Canada, about one in ten people will report capital gains in a given year. In 2021, nearly half of those in the top 1% of income takers reported capital gains, rising to nearly three-quarters of people in the very top 0.01% of the income distribution. Even when average people do post capital gains, they usually aren’t very high.
Tax filers in the top 1% of incomes had capital gains about 7.5 times higher than the bottom 99%, while those in the top 0.01% had gains over 57 times higher. For those at the top of the income ladder, average capital gains for those who had any were many times higher than average labour income for the vast majority of people.
As a result, capital gains are extremely concentrated in the hands of people with very high incomes and lots of concentrated wealth. According to economist Jim Stanford, the top 1.5% of tax filers booked 61% of all capital gains – he notes that there is no other form of income that is more concentrated at the top (p. 9).
The capital gains exclusion loophole is almost entirely a tax-free treat for the rich and corporations – perhaps that explains the ferocity of the counter reaction to such a modest tax hike.

text:
Data: Capital gains tax rates in Europe from 2011-2023
In general, international data or statistics on capital gains tax rates (CGT rate) are not easy to come by. This analysis relies on data published by the Tax Foundation on the top capital gains tax rates for individuals in over twenty European countries.
Note, up until now we have been talking about the capital gains inclusion rate in Canada, how much is counted as taxable income, while this data deals with the actual top tax rates on capital gains in each country. With this data, we are comparing the actual top tax rates paid on capital gains by individuals, regardless of how that country taxes capital gains.
There are two periods covered, one from 2011-2014 and one from 2019-2023. I’m not aware of another data source to fill those years in, other than meticulous manual gathering from public records, which isn’t on the table right now.







Putting this dataset together requires some simplification for the purposes of comparison, since the way capital gains are treated can vary greatly across tax systems. Hover over countries marked by an asterisk to see notes on the data provided by the Tax Foundation.
This data set was combined with macro level economic data from the World Inequality Database and the OECD’s Productivity Statistics Database for comparison against capital gains tax rates.

section: Capital gains tax rates not strongly linked to growth
text:
Capital gains tax rates not strongly linked to growth
A striking episode of evidence free tax fear-mongering on behalf of capital came from the C.D. Howe Institute, which issued a report predicting a very small increase in capital gains taxes will inflict billions in economic damage, costing hundreds of thousands of jobs.
Can a truly modest tax increase on capital bring about economic mass destruction according to so-called “financial theory?”
Well, what can we observe from data when countries actually change their capital gains tax rates in the real world? According to the Tax Foundation’s data, 2011-2012 were banner years for capital gains tax reform and likely tax reform in general, as many European countries were pursuing somewhat more progressive tax policies in response to the revenue fallout of the Great Recession just a few years prior.
Several countries, some of the largest economies in Europe at that, instituted a change in their top personal CGT rate from 2011 through to 2012. Below are the notable examples of countries that raised their CGT rate in 2012. That includes two that went from having no gains taxes to instituting a CGT rate of 25%, which is near the European average, Austria and Portugal. Italy went in the opposite direction, slashing it’s CGT rate from 45 down to 20%, but it did little to benefit their moribund economy.
The table below compares average GDP growth in the decade prior (2001-2011) to the CGT rate change to the tax-year and the next five years (2012-2017). There is not a clear relationship between changes in the CGT rate and economic growth that applies across all countries. Some raised the CGT rate and then outpaced their historical growth trend, while others raised their rates and then slightly under-performed over the next few years.







It stands to reason that it is possible for changes in the CGT rate to have a macro level economic impact observable in growth rate changes. Yet as we can see plainly, even major changes in the CGT rate, including the shock of moving away from zero capital gains taxes, the impact on growth had to be minimal, with countries mostly staying in line with their long-term growth trajectories.
Now, I don’t endorse using GDP or GDP growth as a measure of economic well-being, but in this context it yields zero evidence of the doom-and-gloom theorized by certain advocates of capital. Below, we look into the relationship between the CGT rate and some more meaningful variables of interest.

section: Human need versus tax treats for the rich
text:
Human need versus tax treats for the rich
Despite rising total government spending, Canada’s vital public services and social programs face chronic under-funding from all levels of government. All across the country, public health care and education systems are crumbling, while provincial governments break new ground in privatization efforts.
While the causes of these trends are no doubt complex, much of it comes down insufficient public spending in those areas. The flip side of inadequate spending is insufficient revenue. In recent decades, Canada’s federal and provincial governments, especially in Ontario, have issued tax cuts that have mostly benefited the wealthy or businesses, making Canada’s tax system more regressive, while reducing revenues available to fund public services and investment in public goods.
As we saw demonstrated in charts two and three, there is a connection between the progressiveness of a tax system, social and economic inequality and the spending priorities of governments. Each dollar lost into regressive tax loopholes for the rich represents a wasted opportunity for something better.
Partial inclusion of capital gains is one of the most hefty tax expenditures by Canadian governments each year. From 2019 to 2024, the Canadian federal government spent over $168 billion to fund the capital gains exemption. That’s about $15 billion less than federal tax expenditures on the Canada Child Benefit in the same time span, a program that made a real impact on child poverty.
The chart below compares annual federal tax expenditures on the capital gains loophole versus the Canada Health Transfer (CHT) from 2019 to 2024. The CHT is the federal government’s main way of contributing to the funding of Canada’s health care systems, which exist under provincial jurisdiction.
In total, the Canadian federal government spent about $168 billion on the capital gains exclusion over five years, an average of about $26 billion per year. That means the federal government spent on average around 65% as much on making half of capital gains tax free – mostly for the wealthy and corporations – as they did on the main transfer that funds health care. In 2021, tax-free capital gains cost the public almost much (91%) as the entire CHT.
